TpmPresent  : False
Description : BitLocker is not enabled. No TPM found on this machine, this check is probably irrelevant.

Description: Check whether file extensions such as '.bat' or '.wsh' are associated to a text editor. Note that only basic text editors such as 'Notepad' are detected. If a rich text editor is set instead, this check could yield false positives.

Value       : DisableCoInstallers
Data        : (null)
Description : Driver Co-installers are enabled (default).

Description: Check whether there are COM servers registered with a non-existent module using a relative path. This may not necessarily result in a privilege escalation. You would also need to have rights to create files in a PATH folder. Further analysis is required.
Check whether known vulnerable kernel drivers are installed. It does so by computing the file hash of each driver and comparing the value against the list provided by loldrivers.io.
Check whether the UAC prompt displayed when attempting an application repair through the Windows Installer was disabled.

Value       : DisableLUAInRepair
Data        : (null)
Description : The User Account Control (UAC) prompts for credentials before initiating an application repair.

Description: Check whether there are cached Group Policy Preference (GPP) files that contain clear-text passwords.
Check whether SCCM NAA credentials are stored in the WMI repository. If so, the username and password DPAPI blobs are returned, but can only be decrypted using the SYSTEM's DPAPI user key.
Check whether any environment variables contain sensitive information such as credentials or secrets. Note that this check follows a keyword-based approach and thus might not be completely reliable.

Check whether a well-known VNC server (RealVNC, TigerVNC, TightVNC, UltraVNC) is installed. If so, it attempts to read and decrypt the encrypted password. Note that this might require administrator privileges.
Check whether the SCCM cache folders contain files with potentially hard coded credentials, or secrets, using basic keywords such as 'password', or 'secret'.

Check whether there are scheduled tasks configured with hardcoded credentials (logon type 'Password'), in which case the user account's password is stored in a reversible format in the registry, and can be extracted with administrator privileges.

Check whether LSA protection is enabled. Note that when LSA protection is enabled, 'lsass.exe' runs as a Protected Process Light (PPL) and thus can only be accessed by other protected processes with an equivalent or higher protection level.
ResultRawString:
Key         : HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\Lsa
Value       : RunAsPPL
Data        : (null)
Description : LSA Protection is not enabled.

Description: Check whether there are services configured with hardcoded credentials, in which case the service account's password is likely to be stored in a reversible format in the registry, and can be extracted with administrator privileges.

Check whether Credential Guard is supported and enabled. Note that when Credential Guard is enabled, credentials are stored in an isolated process ('LsaIso.exe') that cannot be accessed, even if the kernel is compromised.
